data.message:
Hi Stuart,

David, the Principal Customer Success Account Manager at Microsoft, replied my coffee chat request as below. I’m not quite sure if he is asking a specific question that needs to be answered, or I can just skip the details and request a coffee in person.
I drafted a response, could you please take a look at it and see if adjustments needed? I

—
Dear David,
Prior to Yale I helped lead B2B strategy at LANDZ, the #1 ranked prop tech firm in local niche, growing annual GMV to $700M / yr. I’m interested in expanding my professional network.
Connect here?
Jamie
-
David, thanks for connecting - appreciate it.
It looks like you’re doing great things at Microsoft. After Yale, I’ve been focused on B2B go-to-market strategy in the cloud-based enterprise software and digital solutions space.
I’m interested in discussing my professional situation or just getting some advice on it.
Please note, I’m not asking for a job. You are in a unique position to offer valuable assistance, and I would be respectful of your time.
Would you have time to grab an e-coffee?
If not, no problem.
Jamie
-
His response:

Hi Jamie, B2B in what sense, mostly from a MSFT perspective is having B2B clients use our Azure cloud Marketplace Services to expand their potential TAM (Total Available Market), but at the end of the day it comes down to the product/service they are selling and what the value add is. Are you in NY as well, and yes interested in discussing futher.
-
My drafted response:

Hi David, thanks for sharing your perspective. I totally agree—B2B success isn’t just about getting more clients or pushing more solutions, but really about creating a win-win where customers consistently derive value from what we offer. Understanding each customer’s unique business context and helping them solve their challenges has been a central focus of my work experience, and I’m looking to keep building on that.
I’m around NYC and happy to explore that further when we meet. What's a good time and location for you?
Look forward to it.
Best,
Jamie
data.author: Jamie Yun

data.message:
Nice work!
Skipping the details - you mean not being interactive or acknowledging his comment?
I would recommend giving this person a sense that they were heard or listened to as part of the response.
Is the next step to request for coffee?
You already requested this. He said yes. So move to the next step.
Think about and draft a response and and I can comment?
data.author: Stuart Bradley

data.message:
Stuart Bradley Hi Stuart, thanks for the comment. Here is the drafted response:
Hi David, thanks for sharing your perspective. I totally agree—B2B success isn’t just about getting more clients or pushing more solutions, but really about creating a win-win where customers consistently derive value from what we offer. Understanding each customer’s unique business context and helping them solve their challenges has been a central focus of my work experience, and I’m looking to keep building on that.
I’m around NYC and happy to explore that further when we meet. What's a good time and location for you?
Look forward to it.
Best,
Jamie
data.author: Jamie Yun

data.message: Jamie Yun looks fine to me
data.author: Stuart Bradley

data.message: this MSFT feedback is the biggest win so far in your chat. There is still a gap between your statement of focus and someone understanding how and what you want to do
data.author: Stuart Bradley
